quote:
A most notable coward, an infinite and endless liar, an hourly promise breaker, the owner of no one good quality.

All’s Well That Ends Well (Act 3, Scene 6)

Aroint thee: go away, rump-fed runion: slut

Macbeth (Act 1 Scene 3)

Away thou rag, thou quantity, thou remnant.

Taming of the Shrew (Act 4, Scene 3)

Away, you mouldy rogue, away!

Henry IV (Act 2, Scene 2)

Away, you starvelling, you elf-skin, you dried neat’s-tongue, bull’s-pizzle, you stock-fish!

Henry IV Part 1 (Act 2, Scene 4)

Away, you three-inch fool!

The Taming of the Shrew (Act 4, Scene 1)

A whoreson, beetle-headed, flap-eared knave!

The Taming of the Shrew (Act 4, Scene 1)

Come, come, you froward and unable worms!

The Taming Of The Shrew (Act 5, Scene 2)

Foul-spoken coward, that thund’rest with thy tongue, and with thy weapon nothing dar’st perform.

Titus Andronicus (Act 2, Scene 1)

Go, prick thy face, and over-red thy fear, Thou lily-liver’d boy.

Macbeth (Act 5, Scene 3)

He has not so much brain as ear-wax.

Troilus and Cressida (Act 5, Scene 1)

Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hell

Othello (Act 4, Scene 2)

Here is the babe, as loathsome as a toad.

Titus Andronicus (Act 4, Scene 3)

His wit’s as thick as a Tewkesbury mustard.

Henry IV Part 2 (Act 2, Scene 4)

How now, thou crusty batch of nature!

Troilus and Cressida (Act 5, Scene 1)

I am pigeon-liver’d and lack gall.

Hamlet (Act 2, Scene 2)

I am sick when I do look on thee

A Midsummer Night’s Dream (Act 2, Scene 1)

I can’t say your worships have delivered the matter well, when I find the ass in compound with the major part of your syllables.

Coriolanus (Act 2, Scene 1)

I do desire that we may be better strangers.

As You Like It (ACt 3, Scene 2)

I do wish thou wert a dog, that I might love thee something. 

Timon of Athens (Act 4, Scene 3)

I must tell you friendly in your ear, sell when you can, you are not for all markets.

As You Like It (Act 3 Scene 5)

I scorn you, scurvy companion.

Henry IV Part II (Act 2, Scene 4)

If thou wilt needs marry, marry a fool; for wise men know well enough what monsters you make of them.

Hamlet (Act 3, Scene 1)

I’ll beat thee, but I would infect my hands.

Timon of Athens (Act 4, Scene 3)

Like the toad; ugly and venomous.

As You Like It (Act 2, Scene 1)

Live loathed and long, most smiling, smooth, detested parasites.

Timon of Athens (Act 3, Scene 6)

Methink’st thou art a general offence and every man should beat thee

All’s Well That Ends Well (Act 2, Scene 3)

More of your conversation would infect my brain.

Coriolanus (Act 2, Scene 1)

My wife’s a hobby horse!

The Winter’s Tale (Act 2, Scene 1)

No longer from head to foot than from hip to hip, she is spherical, like a globe; I could find countries in her.

The Comedy of Errors (Act 3, Scene 2)

Out of my sight! Thou dost infect mine eyes.

Richard III (Act 1, Scene 2)

Peace, ye fat guts!

Henry IV Part 1 (Act 2, Scene 2)

She hath more hair than wit, and more faults than hairs.

Two Gentlemen of Verona (Act 3, Scene 1)

She speaks yet she says nothing.

Romeo and Juliet (Act 2, Scene 2)

That poisonous bunch-back’d toad!

Richard III (Act 1, Scene 3)

That trunk of humours, that bolting-hutch of beastliness, that swollen parcel of dropsies, that huge bombard of sack, that stuffed cloak-bag of guts, that roasted Manningtree ox with pudding in his belly, that reverend vice, that grey Iniquity, that father ruffian, that vanity in years?

Henry IV Part 1 (Act 2, Scene 4)

The rankest compound of villainous smell that ever offended nostril

The Merry Wives of Windsor (Act 3, Scene 5)

The tartness of his face sours ripe grapes.

The Comedy of Errors (Act 5, Scene 4)

There’s no more faith in thee than in a stewed prune.

Henry IV Part 1 (Act 3, Scene 3)

They have a plentiful lack of wit.

Hamlet (ACt 2, Scene 2)

They lie deadly that tell you you have good faces.

Coriolanus (Acet 2, Scene 1)

Thine forward voice, now, is to speak well of thine friend; thine backward voice is to utter foul speeches and to detract.

The Tempest (Act 2, Scene 2)

This kiss is as comfortless as frozen water to a starved snake.

Titus Andronicus (Act 3, Scene 1)

This leathern-jerkin, crystal-button, knot-pated, agate-ring, puke-stocking, caddis-garter, smooth-tongue, Spanish pouch!

Henry IV Part 1 (Act 2, Scene 4)

This woman’s an easy glove, my lord, she goes off and on at pleasure.

All’s Well That Ends Well (Act 5, Scene 3)

Thou art a boil, a plague sore, an embossed carbuncle in my corrupted blood.

King Lear (Act 2, Scene 2)

Thou art a very ragged wart.

Henry IV (Act 3, Scene 2)

Thou art as fat as butter.

Henry IV Part 1 (Act 2, Scene 4)

Thou art the cap of all the fools alive.

Timon of Athens (Act4, Scene 3)

Thou art unfit for any place but hell.

Richard III (Act 1 Scene 2)

Thou clay-brained guts, thou knotty-pated fool, thou whoreson obscene greasy tallow-catch!

Henry IV Part 1 (Act 2, Scene 4 )

Thou cream faced loon

Macbeth (Act 5, Scene 3)

Thou damned and luxurious mountain goat.

Henry V (Act 4, Scene 4)

Thou elvish-mark’d, abortive, rooting hog!

Richard III (Act 1, Scene 3)

Thou lump of foul deformity

Richard III (Act 1, Scene 2)

Thou sodden-witted lord! Thou hast no more brain than I have in mine elbows

Troilus and Cressida (Act 2, Scene 1)

Thou subtle, perjur’d, false, disloyal man!

The Two Gentlemen of Verona (Act 4, Scene 2)

Thou whoreson zed, thou unnecessary letter!

King Lear (Act 2, Scene 2 )

Thou’rt poison to my blood.

Cymbeline (Act 1, Scene 1)

Thy sin’s not accidental, but a trade.

Measure For Measure (Act 3, Scene 1)

Thy tongue outvenoms all the worms of Nile.

Cymbeline (Act 3, Scene 4)

Villain, I have done thy mother

Titus Andronicus (Act 4, Scene 2)

Virginity breeds mites, much like a cheese.

All’s Well That Ends Well (Act 1, Scene 1)

Was the Duke a flesh-monger, a fool and a coward?

Measure For Measure (Act 5, Scene 1)

What hempen home-spuns have we swaggering here

A Midsummer Night’s Dream, (Act 3, Scene 1)

What, you egg? Young fry of treachery!

Macbeth (Act 4, Scene 2)

Would thou wert clean enough to spit upon

Timon of Athens (Act 4, Scene 3)

Would thou wouldst burst!

Timon of Athens (Act 4, Scene 3)

You Banbury cheese!

The Merry Wives of Windsor (Act 1, Scene 1)

You are as a candle, the better burnt out.

Henry IV Part 2 (Act 1, Scene 2)

You are not worth another word, else I’d call you knave.

All’s Well that Ends Well (Act 2, Scene 3)

You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things.

Julius Caesar (Act 1, Scene 1)

You cankerblossom.

A Midsummer Night’s Dream (Act 3, Scene 2)

You common cry of curs, whose breath I hate as reek o’ th’ rotten fens.

Coriolanus (Act 3, Scene 3)

You have such a February face, So full of frost, of storm, and cloudiness.

Much Ado About Nothing (Act 5, Scene 4)

You kiss by the book.

Romeo and Juliet (Act 1, Scene 5)

You poor, base, rascally, cheating lack-linen mate!

Henry IV Part II (Act 2, Scene 4)

You scullion! You rampallian! You fustilarian! I’ll tickle your catastrophe!

Henry IV Part 2 (Act 2, Scene 1)

You starvelling, you eel-skin, you dried neat’s-tongue, you bull’s-pizzle, you stock-fish–O for breath to utter what is like thee!-you tailor’s-yard, you sheath, you bow-case, you vile standing tuck!

Henry IV Part 1 (Act 2, Scene 4)

You, minion, are too saucy.

The Two Gentlemen of Verona (ACt 1, Scene 2)

Your abilities are too infant-like for doing much alone.

Coriolanus (Act 2, Scene 1)

His brain is as dry as the remainder biscuit after a voyage.

As You Like It (Act 2, Scene 7)

There's small choice in rotten apples

Taming of the Shrew(Act 1, Scene 1)

Whose face is not worth sunburning.

Henry V (Act 5, Scene 2)
